info.document:
By most accounts, Epic Systems Corp.'s announcement that it was releasing a digital tool allowing patients to share their medical records with any provider was a huge leap toward reaching the ever-elusive digital exchange of medical information.

Share Everywhere allows a patient using the Epic mobile app to let any new provider see his or her medical record through a web browser. All the provider needs is a computer and internet access. That provider can also add notes to the record, which are sent to the originating healthcare organization.

"The advantages are huge from a patient perspective," said David Muntz, principal at health IT consultancy StarBridge Advisors and former principal deputy at HHS' Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology. "We used to see wheelchairs moving charts from the car to the office, literally, and this has eliminated that challenge."

Epic said it's been chipping away at lack of interoperability -- long hindered by technical complexity and privacy concerns -- with many of its products.

Indeed, Share Everywhere does help patients get their medical records from one provider to another and could help meet meaningful use requirements. But the data patients grant access to are not integrated into the receiving provider's EHR system. The receiving provider doesn't even need to have an EHR.
